title: Committee Charter
text:
General
The committee will meet at a minimum every 5 weeks. Our goal is to build a robust network of ECR Informatics researchers across the UK DRI and to provide these researchers with meetings and opportunities relevant to their interests, that will help their research and career development.


Committee Chair
There will be two co-chairs at any time. These will be decided on every year after Connectome. One co-chair will run from March-March, the other co-chair will be from November-November. If there is more than two nominations a vote will be held. It is the chair’s responsibility to organise meetings roughly every 5 weeks and manage the projects of the committee.


Secretary
Secretary will be rotated between other ECR members (not co-chairs) on a rota basis, so that a different member takes this role every time. Committee notes will be shared on our Github repo, making them available to everyone within the UKDRI Github organisation where ever this is sensible.


Membership of the committee
We will try to have at least one member from each UK DRI centre doing informatics. Currently if a member decides to step down they should make efforts to find a replacement.
If a member doesn’t attend two meetings in a row without contacting the committee with a reasonable explanation, they will be removed from the committee. Members are expected to check the Slack channel (#theme-esc-informatics) and emails from the committee.

title: Discoveries
text:
You can find the form to add new discoveries here: https://forms.gle/PCpRe214Jjptm8Cz8

title: Kiran K G Ravindran
text: I am a Postdoctoral Researcher at the Surrey Sleep Research Centre, University of Surrey, and UK DRI Care Research & Technology Centre (CRT) at Imperial College London and University of Surrey, Guildford. I am a biomedical engineer interested in all things “SLEEP”! I joined the committee to represent the data analytics and machine learning side of CRT.

title: Gabriel Mateus Bernardo Harrington
text:
I’m a post-doc bioinformatician in the Webber lab in the Cardiff UKDRI. I work mainly on Alzheimer’s disease with a focus on the neurovasculature side of things, typically working with single nuclei seq data.
I’ve a big interest in reproducibility in science! A lot of science isn’t done to a particularly high standard, so I’m very keen to try and help build community around better practises in the UKDRI (Git repo templates, training, support networks, etc). I’d like to make it easier for folk to adopt better practises and make their science more transparent so we can all learn from each other and beat these unpleasent diseases sooner :)

title: Christina Maat
text: In the labs of Soyon Hong (UKDRI at UCL) and Kenneth Harris (Cortex Lab at UCL) I am studying the role of microglia in Alzheimer’s Disease using spatial transcriptomics. When learning to work with advanced data analysis methods, I realized that we were not making full use of the incredibly rich informatics community at the UKDRI. By creating means for (starting) informaticians to connect - through events or digital platforms - I hope to contribute to making the informatics community a place that both propels cutting-edge computational approaches in dementia research and serves as a springboard to those breaking into the field.

title: Maryam Shoai
text:
Affiliated and member of UKDRI and ECR Informatics committee since creation.
Who: I am a senior research fellow in statistical genetics and have been working in the Hardy lab.
Why? I joined the ECR committee with the hope of helping to create a support network of informaticians/statisticians with varying degrees of experience for researchers in Genomics, Informatics and Statistics. It doesn’t matter if you are a master of the craft or a beginner, we want to form a network that will enrich your ECR experience.

title: New committee members needed!
text:
We’re looking to recruit some new members to the committee!
We’d really like to have representation from each centre, so folk from the Cambridge and Kings DRI centres would be especially welcome. Having said that, we don’t’ intend to be exclusionary, so if you’re keen to be involved you’re very welcome regardless :)
We’d also like to try and have folk representing different aspect of informatic work, and we’re missing a member working with imaging data, so that’d also be great!

title: Welcome!
text:
This is the first post for the UKDRI ECR informatics committee website!
For now we’d like this to be a place where people can see who we are and what upcoming events we have, but depending on what the community wants we might also add other stuff (links to nice training material, guest blog posts, etc).
Feel free to get in touch if you’ve thoughts you want to share!

title: Behind the P-value
text:
We have a new seminar series starting that we’re calling Behind the p-value!
You can find details, a calendar invite and the zoom link to join on the DRI portal here.
Here’s the pitch:
Informatics are used in many papers, but the methods and decisions used to generate the figures are often unclear. Why did they choose one package over another? How were the data filtered, and why were those filters chosen? Why UMAP and not tSNE, or vice versa?
The Informatics ECR committee invite you to a different kind of seminar that aims to focus on the informatics analyses that underlie published work.
Join us as Dr. Anna Mallach, Edmond and Lily Safra Research Fellow and UKDRI Emerging Leader at Imperial, discusses the methods and decisions she used when analysing data for her recent paper in Cell Reports (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.celrep.2024.114216).

title: Steve Hill
text: I am an Alzheimer’s Society Fellow in the lab of Blanca Díaz Castro (UKDRI at Edinburgh). My current work primarily uses proteomics to study astrocyte endfeet. I am a trained molecular biologist and self-taught in informatics data analyses. I joined the committee to bridge the gap between the wet lab scientists and informaticians of the UK DRI. I try to represent my experience from this perspective to ensure the theme is inclusive to all levels of experience.

title: David Cash
text:
I’m a professorial research fellow at the Dementia Research Centre in the UCL Queen Square Institute of Neurology, where I lead the imaging and data management activities for high-profile studies in ageing (the Insight 46 neuroimaging sub-study of the MRC National Survey for Health and Development) and global multicentre studies in autosomal dominant forms of Alzheimer’s disease and frontotemporal dementia (GENFI). I have medical imaging acquisition, analysis and data management experiences in both academic and industrial settings. I worked five years at IXICO Ltd, a medical imaging contract research organisation, where I managed the imaging in clinical trials in Alzheimer’s disease and oncology for various pharmaceutical sponsors. I collobarate heavily with the Hawkes Institute (formerly known as Centre for Medical Image Computing (CMIC)) to help translate cutting edge informatics and medical imaging analysis techniques are being implemented into clinical research.
I am also the primary investigator on Health and Bioscience IDEAS, a UK Research and Innovation funded programme to train researchers on how to use medical imaging data more effectively within their work. We have developed numerous interactive coding workshops helping researchers get involved with medical imaging analysis and data management.
I have an active role on various national and international committees working on imaging in Alzheimer’s disease, including the Dominantly Inherited Alzheimer Network (DIAN), the Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI), the GENetic Frontotemporal Initiative (GENFI). I am Immediate Past Chair of the ISTAART Neuroimaging PIA, an organization of over 1700 neuroimaging researchers working in dementia.

title: here
text: Useful for managing file paths in Quarto/R Markdown files. If you have a nested .qmd or .rmd and want to put file paths in, you’ll know when they render they set the working directory to the location of that file and not the project root.

title: here
text: Useful for managing file paths in Quarto/R Markdown files. If you have a nested .qmd or .rmd and want to put file paths in, you’ll know when they render they set the working directory to the location of that file and not the project root.

title: here
text:
Example Usage

# Create a new project, check you've got a .Rproj file in the project root.
# you can then just use the function:
here::here() # get the project path

# Example reading fake file
file <- here::here("data_folder/example_table.csv")
print(file)
# Read in data
# data <- read.csv(file)

title: here
text:
Additional Resources

Source Code: https://github.com/r-lib/here/

title: janitor
text: I use it most often immediately after I read in a file to clean the column names. It’ll do things like remove special characters and replace spaces with underscores.

title: janitor
text: I use it most often immediately after I read in a file to clean the column names. It’ll do things like remove special characters and replace spaces with underscores.

title: janitor
text:
Example Usage

# Data with dirty column names
head(iris)

  Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa
2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa
3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa
4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa
5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa
6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

# Easy cleaning!
iris |>
  janitor::clean_names() |>
  head()

  sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species
1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa
2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa
3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa
4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa
5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa
6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

title: janitor
text:
Additional Resources

Source Code: https://github.com/sfirke/janitor

title: Pierre Parutto
text: Hello there! I am currently a postdoctoral researcher at the department of Clinical Neurosciences at the University of Cambridge and UKDRI. I work at the intersection between cellular biology, neurosciences, microscopy and data modelling with a particular interest in explaining complex biological systems from first principles.

title: Bioinformatics Bytes Café
text:
The inaugural Bioinformatics Bytes Café is scheduled for 2025-02-28 at 14:00 via Zoom, please come along!
The idea here is to get informatics folks together, sharing cool ideas and chatting. We’ll be starting with a discoveries session where we showcase some cool tools/packages rapid fire. Then we’ll have a brief presentation around the UK DRI GitHub and we’ll finish with a discussion session.
We’re very open to changing this structure if that’s what folk want, so please get in touch with any feedback, we are here for you! 😄
You don’t have to be a hardcore informatician, if you’re learning or planning to learn informatics related stuff then you are part of the community and should be there!
You can find details, a calendar invite and the zoom link to join on the DRI portal here.
Hope to see many of you there!
